column1: Recruitment, Promotion & Pipeline:  Has your organization performed an organization-wide review to identify teams that have no or low gender diversity (ie - "the lonely only" - one woman, one female of color, one LGBTQ-identifying person, one woman who is differently-abled)?
column2: Recruitment, Promotion & Pipeline:  If a review has been conducted, what have been the results?
column3: Recruitment, Promotion & Pipeline: Have you designed and implemented a recruitment process to eliminate gender equity bias?
column4: Statement about gender equity goals in recruitment on all job postings
column5: Process in-place (with designated and trained teammates or usage of technology) to review and revise job descriptions prior to posting to ensure gender-biased language is eliminated
column6: Move toward skills-based competencies and growth mindsets and away from focus on certain schools, prior experiences
column7: Requirement to post jobs on a diverse group of job boards, recruiting firms, etc to ensure opportunities are accessible to a diverse candidate pool
column8: Blind resume review and blind auditions (as applicable)
column9: Training for HR and all hiring managers on how to identify and reduce gender equity biases throughout the recruitment process
column10: Oversight and support by trained HR or other designated-internal teams to ensure unbiased recruitment process
column11: Oversight by a third-party entity to identify and reduce bias from recruitment process
column13: Recruitment, Promotion & Pipeline:  Have gender diverse numeric targets been established - at all steps in the recruitment process -  to ensure a diverse slate of candidates?
column14: Recruitment, Promotion & Pipeline:  If gender diverse numeric targets have been in place for at least 12 months, have those targets been met?
column15: Recruitment, Promotion & Pipeline:  Does your organization on-board new employees using cohorts designed to avoid "one-ness" (only woman, only person of color)?
column16: Recruitment, Promotion & Pipeline:  Has your organization implemented a performance review program designed to eliminate gender bias?
column17: Recruitment, Promotion & Pipeline:  Have all managers received training, that includes an anti-bias component, on how to implement unbiased gender equity performance reviews?
column18: Recruitment, Promotion & Pipeline:  Do you track success rate of managers of entry-level women to see that women and men are all getting promoted at equal rates from entry level?
column19: Recruitment, Promotion & Pipeline:  Are results tracked to determine whether gender bias has been reduced or eliminated from performance reviews?
column20: Recruitment, Promotion & Pipeline:  Tell us more about how your organization has tracked performance review results.
column22: % Promoted Workers who identify as Women
column23: Women who identify as Black or African American
column26: Women who identify as Native American/Alaskan/Pacific Islander
column27: Women who identify as Mixed Race
column31: Persons who identify as gender non-binary
column33: Give us feedback - how challenging is it to provide internal promotion details for your workforce to the degree asked above?
column34: Recruitment, Promotion & Pipeline:  If your organization had targets for internal promotion of candidates reflecting gender equity goals, did you meet your goals?
column35: Recruitment, Promotion & Pipeline:  Does your organization have a program to retain and promote gender diverse entry and mid-level workers through training, development and other professional development opportunities?
column36: Recruitment, Promotion & Pipeline:  If you responded yes or in development, tell us more about the  program to retain and promote gender diverse entry and mid-level workers through training, development and other professional development opportunities.
column37: Recruitment, Promotion & Pipeline:  What % of gender diverse workers participated in these types of programs during the last 12 months?
column38: Recruitment, Promotion & Pipeline:  During the last 12 months, were participants in these programs promoted at the same or higher rates than all employees across the organization?{{field:70ab1a1c-026b-427f-9511-faed18c9e883}}
column39: Recruitment, Promotion & Pipeline:  What % of training and development budget is allocated toward the gender diverse pipeline development programs covered in the questions above?
column40: At the secondary or tertiary education level
column41: At the on-ramping/workforce re-entry level for mid-career women
column44: Recruitment, Promotion & Pipeline:  During the last 12 months, what percentage of participants in these programs have been hired into a full-time role?
column45: Recruitment, Promotion & Pipeline: Before we move to the next section, is there anything else you want to tell us about how your organization tracks, reports on or is working to improve its recruitment, promotion and pipeline development?

column20: We have reviewed all manager assessments of employees, looking at the gender of the manager and the gender of the employee. Overall, we saw that there were little differences across gender in the assessment - when comparing to the company averages. Most notably, it was women managers who tend to assess their women employees slightly lower than the company average. Whereas men managers assessed their women employees at the same rate as the company average, or slightly higher than the company average.
